true audio/euro_m3-5_s38.mp3 false View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q1.jpg View images/euro_m3-5_s38_q2.jpg

The photo was taken on the same street as the earlier photo of Lodz that you analyzed. What, if anything, has changed?

The ghetto has been abandoned false A bridge over the street has replaced the gated crossing true The ghetto is no longer divided into sections by the thoroughfare false The ghetto boundaries have changed false Nothing has changed false 2

All of the following might be explanations for the building of a pedestrian bridge for the ghetto inhabitants EXCEPT

it would allow trams and cars to drive freely through the ghetto false it would allow ghetto population to cross the street at any time false it would cut down on the manpower required to monitor the street crossings false it would protect the Jews from being run over true it would reduce the amount of contact between Germans and Jews false

Who is likely in the tram pictured in the photo?

Polish or German civilians true German Military men false Jews moving into the ghetto false Tourists from outside Lodz who have come to see the ghetto false A Jewish police patrol false

What message does the existence of the bridge reinforce?

That the Germans were concerned about Jewish safety false That Jews should be allowed to move more freely around the city false That the Jews inhabit a completely separate universe and cannot even touch the street designated to non-Jews. true That Jews wanted to be isolated from the rest of the citizens of Lodz false That the Jews in the ghetto needed to be protected from the Polish and German inhabitants of Lodz false

Many of the Jews on the bridge appear to be looking down at the street. The street may have represented all of the following to them EXCEPT

a symbol of their confinement false a longing for freedom false their lives before Nazi occupation false a reminder of what has been taken away from them false a place they no longer wish to walk true

The non-Jewish inhabitants of Lodz were allowed to travel this street. Which of the following would have contributed most to their knowledge about and understanding of what was going on in the ghetto?

Observing the bridge false Asking German guards about life in the ghetto false Travelling down the street in a tram and looking at the buildings false The fact that only a wooden and barbed wire fence stood between them and the ghetto inhabitants true Getting messages passed to them from ghetto inhabitants as they passed by false

Who is most likely to have taken this photo?

An official German military or civil photographer true A Polish or German citizen traveling through on a tram false A Jewish inhabitant of the ghetto false A visiting journalist from a neutral country false A member of the Jewish police force false

Whose point of view is represented by this photograph?

The point of view of the Jewish inhabitants of the ghetto false The point of view of Polish and German civilian inhabitants of Lodz false The point of view of a tourist to Lodz false The point of view of the German military and civil administrators of the ghetto true The point of view of the Jewish leadership of the ghetto. false

The point of view expressed in the photograph can be summarized by completing the following statement with all of the following EXCEPT ‘The Jews of Lodz are confined behind barbed wire and kept separate from the surrounding community…’

for their own safety true so that the German occupiers can exploit their labor false so that the Germans can keep them under their control until they decide what to do with them false because the Germans believe they are a menace and a danger to the so-called ‘master-race’ false because the Germans have deemed them inferior and ‘unworthy of life’ false

Taken together, these images most convey which of the following?

The attitude of all Germans towards Jewish people in the 1930s. false The growing fear and hatred of the Jews by some in Europe in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. true Jews were better off being separated from Christians in Western Europe. false Jews controlled the banks in Western Europe and could not be trusted. false Discrimination of Jewish people was commonplace and accepted throughout all of Western Europe. false
